criticReviews.criticPost: How much patience you can summon will prove key.

The (Williams) brothers are to be applauded for making complex television that requires viewer commitment to a bewildering jumble of plots, time zones and locations. Fortunately, it is a winning combination.
Stick with it, because it gets easier and it promises to be one hell of an edge-of-your-seat story.
I won't write this off yet - I'll be back for more next week, mainly for Hawes and Morrissey - but let's hope that the second series of The Missing isn't let down by another anti-climax.
The acting is exemplary, deeply felt and mesmerisingly naturalistic, and Chanan's direction creates an ominous atmosphere of dread and anxiety.
The Missing on BBC1 is like televisual Sudoku, yet it is utterly compelling, brilliantly acted and written, and a match for the much-lauded Scandinavian noir of recent years.
It is ... like the first series, a deeply human story about loss and grief and blame, and what something like this would do to a marriage and to a family.
Series two's opening episode, featuring a brand new story and a new missing child / children, hits all the right notes, with heaps of intrigue and a mightily impressive new cast.

The Missing does an excellent job of making its many, many twists feel like natural reveals, and it moves along at a quick pace while leaving enough time to explore the difficult and complicated emotions of its leads.

While some TV dramas go perfectly with a vat of tea and a chocolate hobnob, and others sit well with a glass of wine, the best accompaniment to The Missing season two might be a flipchart, multi-coloured board markers and a stack of Post-It Notes.
A sobering, haunting and profoundly complex, yet profoundly human, crime drama. It is recommended with a caveat - it is at times shockingly dark and will disturb you to your bones.
What emerges is another beyond-twisty mystery, one that grows more gripping and densely layered as this eight-episode limited series unfolds.
The Missing's greatest strength is front and center -- an astonishing cast conveying oceans of pain with a blink of an eye.
As before there are parallels, puzzles, ironies and a sense of existential fragility.

Season 2 is the lesser in just about every way. It perks to life at the end, though... And Mr. Karyo's indomitable Baptiste, shrugging in the face of indifference and opposition, should still appeal to any Philip Marlowe fans out there.
The Missing is a fast-paced, tantalizing jigsaw puzzle that successfully juggles multiple timelines, locations and characters, each of which has a connection to the main case.

Baptiste wants to give them a happy ending, without ignoring the haunting lessons. By embracing him - as well as an ambitious premise - The Missing improves in Season 2. And where they go from here remains enticingly unknown.
The Missing is a feast -- albeit the most chilly, emotionally devastating feast ever -- for armchair sleuths.
The series doesn't lack for suspenseful moments, the settings are intriguing, and there's much to be said for the strong performance by Mr. Morrissey and that of Roger Allam.

As it usually goes with mysteries, a viewer's knowledge is best kept minimal before heading into The Missing Season 2, but know that these episodes will leave you with your jaw on the floor at every turn.
I didn't expect the final episode to be such a mixture of neat endings and open-ended misery.

A skepticism toward institutions, both international and domestic, never gets specific enough to become hard-hitting criticism. I'd rather watch a bricklayer at his job; at least he won't pretend there's a larger moral point to his work.
Nesbitt and O'Connor are stunning. Equally brilliant is Tcheky Karyo, who plays the French detective Julien Baptiste.
The Missing is a fascinating, unique, and ambitious piece of storytelling that one can't help but get engrossed in.
While some of The Missing may seem torturous if you are a parent and thinking about your child, the performances, especially Nesbitt's, are compelling.
There is a depth of feeling to it that you connect with, if you have accrued life's experiences of loss, doubt and regret. It is also a bloody brilliant thriller.
It is eight hours long, and I watched it all in a single sitting.

It's very good, a swift-moving crime thriller that also takes the time to measure the effects of the crime on Tony and Emily's marriage, their state of mind, and the lives of the French townspeople who were drawn into the investigation and may be again.
There have been an awful lot of movies and shows about lost children, but The Missing elevates the familiar dynamic to a new level with a gut wrenching mystery.

I liked it enough to want to know how it ends. I'll likely watch the whole thing, but it's one of those shows that has elements that are tough to take, and I'd understand if some potential audience members gave it a miss.
Trodding a timeworn path for television drama, The Missing is nonetheless exquisitely affecting and positively addictive.

Along the way, The Missing does not break many rules or deliver any shockers. It instead brings itself to a slow, sure boil. I was surprised to find myself completely hooked and entirely hopeful that the ending might be just as satisfying the start.

The Missing was made as a thriller, and it is that -- a hard-charging, unfailingly suspenseful mystery whose tonnage of side dramas and veritable school of red herrings don't, miraculously enough, undermine its strength.
"Nothing is certain," a detective reminds Tony. Maybe not, except for The Missing's ability to keep viewers riveted through each shocking twist.

For all of its almost scientific attention to the granular details of shifting emotion and point of view, The Missing also has an eye for beauty. This is one of the year's very best TV programs, hard as it sometimes is to endure.

The Missing is a closed-end series, promising a conclusion at the end of its eight episodes. Painful as that journey may be, the show and these actors hit all the notes that make us want to come along.
The Missing... is sometimes grueling to watch. But it earns a place in haunting crime drama next to the recent Broadchurch and Top of the Lake.

It is a riveting, heartbreaking, fascinating drama, taking a subject that could easily have been turned into a Lifetime TV Movie melodrama and making it real with its subtle, character-driven grace notes and the breakneck speed of its elaborate plotting.
While it may not transcend its genre, The Missing is a strong addition to the canon.

While there's a mystery to be solved at the heart of this eight-episode limited series, this isn't a Liam Neeson Taken-type thriller. It's more of a slow burn, a psychological study in grief, guilt and what can happen to a marriage tested by tragedy.
It isn't exactly great, but it's compulsively watchable.
We expect television programs to be derivative, but Moonlighting doesn't even do its borrowing with finesse.

Moonlighting is a welcome addition to primetime TV, offering a satisfying blend of comedy, romance and action - which in itself is unique. Add to the recipe, the special talents of Willis, and you've got the stuff from which hits are made.

Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles has some of the same problems that has faced the movie franchise...Throughout the season, it was getting hard to keep track of what the Connors' objective was...

Gritty writing, vivid characters and dynamic visual style did not attract enough audience to justify the budget and it was cancelled after the superb season...most riveting is the evolution of the robots, making them more "human" and less predictable.
Weaver's interest in rules -- specifically, in the ways humans don't follow them and computers do -- is of a piece with the series' own.
This season's opener is much clearer and more sheer fun than anything that aired last spring. And Summer Glau is still quite a treat as the robot sent to protect Connor from murderous cyborgs.
The Sarah Connor Chronicles continue to deliver, on a program where surviving in the here and now, finally, is the principal measure of success.
...a classic cliffhanger, but one that opened the door to a wealth of intriguing new possibilities.

The show's mission boils down to "stop the robots, save the world," but always adds wild, often tiring convolutions. My interest ebbs and flows depending not on the plot but on which character is in the action.
The Sarah Connor Chronicles may not be equally compelling from week to week, with some standalone episodes more formulaic than others, but one has to hand it to Friedman and his writing team.
It's a step in the right direction for a series that struggled to live up to its potential and pedigree last spring.
Dekker's Connor has a steel in it we've yet to see in the character. John's finally stepping up to the plate, and it's about damn time.
Things may get worse before they get better (we'll see how McG's movie does next year), but for now, The Sarah Connor Chronicles is holding the line with reasonable aplomb.
While I was skeptical about the quality of the show before I watched The Sarah Connor Chronicles, I was pleasantly surprised by how enjoyable it was.
Strategically it all makes perfect sense, provided that Friedman and company can continue meeting the daunting task of oiling the tracks on this thrill ride.
Focus, if you must, on Sarah Connor as a surprising and rich parable of modern parenting, or better yet, just enjoy the ride.
Certainly, there is some promise to the opening episodes.
Director David Nutter gets the series off to a rousing start, practically packing every frame with suspense, special effects and an urgency that drives this show like an incessant drumbeat
Think too closely about the details and it ruins the fun.
The charismatic Headey is so much more than a gym babe. Headey is nicely balanced by the show's second female lead, Summer Glau.
Smart, tough and entertaining, Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles gets most everything right that Bionic Woman got so glaringly wrong.

James Cameron's name on the writing credits and the sight of a newly rebuilt T unit sitting in a bath of blood go a long way toward making up for certain technological flaws and Lena Headey's eyebrow acting.
Headey is less of an earthy, physical presence than Linda Hamilton was in the films, but her wry and contemplative take on Sarah grew on me.
This effort to bring Sarah's Chronicles both back and forward to our current moment is both awkward and smart.

While it's hard to predict how this new chapter will play among deeper fans of the Terminator mythology, the rest of us have to ask ourselves if watching reboots of robot battles once a week is worth our time.
This grim Chronicles needs to put some flesh on its humans.
After waiting so long and spending so much money to bring back Sarah, the least the producers could have done was to give us someone resembling the Sarah we remember.
Only time will tell if this exhibited teasing is building to something more worthwhile. Until then, Sarah Connor Chronicles will be just another wannabe worshipping at Cameron's altar.
On its own terms, Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles is a serviceable enough addition to this particular pop-culture mosaic.

Fox has taken the wholly predictable course of putting a lot of money into explosions and regenerating cyborgs (and the makeup that helps them) but hasn't paid much attention to plot, casting or writing.
Smart entertainment, full of interesting 3-dimensional characters, and packed with action, excitement, and humor. Terminator fans can rejoice in the fact that they got this show fundamentally right.

One of the more humanizing adventures in science fiction to arrive in quite a while, the series is taut, haunting, relevant and an exploration of adolescent exceptionalism rendered without the cheerleading uniforms.
[An] unexpected twist occurs.
It needs to hold people like Colt and Rooster accountable for their inconsistent morals while still respecting that all voices deserve to be heard.
While it is ostensibly a comedy, its power comes not from jokes but from quiet, contemplative moments of familial conflict and existential crises.

Yes, you can see its crude jokes coming a mile away, and its politics are blithe and often bad (not always, though). But the series is also so pleasingly lived-in and well lit ... and the performances are sharp and appealing.
Even though it doesn't finish the job, Part 3 goes further than its target audience would be comfortable with.
The Bennetts feel real, and so, surprisingly, does their ranch, even if it's just a stage set. (Lighting, and sometimes the lack of lighting, appears to be key.)
At its heart, it's still a sitcom -- funny, just not pandering and silly as most.
What makes [The Ranch] addictively watchable is the invisible professionalism of almost everyone involved.
The comedy is passable at best, with far too many uninspired jokes padding things out.
There is a strange warmth and an ease to the series that makes it just fine for casual watching.
The Ranch is a Netflix original, and one rather lazily done - an instance of the lack of quality control at the streaming service.
There is so much to love about this Netflix comedy.
Brash and off-putting, The Ranch is also bizarrely watchable.
The performances are engaging. Winger is particularly good, thoroughly at ease tossing out sarcasm and wistfulness, and Elliott is close behind her in this regard.

Though the cast is appealing, the jokes and foibles just aren't fresh enough to wring a lot of laughs from its audience, who probably won't be able to shake the feeling that we've seen these characters and heard these jokes before.

The Ranch is a disappointing start to a sitcom with a solid premise packed with talent. The characters are one-note and could benefit from more emotional development, and resolution to their many fights.
There aren't many laugh-out-loud moments, but it is pretty clever and there is some great wordplay and a fun dynamic between brothers Colt and Rooster.

It has the feel of a series that's just getting its legs underneath it, which could lead to great things down the road. For now, it's enjoyable enough, thanks to the way it uses the freedom afforded it by Netflix to try new things with the sitcom format.

After six seasons, you'd think The Walking Dead would become predictable - but Sunday night's season finale likely left even the most hardened longtime fans confused, angry and sick to their stomachs.
There are so many elements of "The Ranch" that were potentially appealing, and yet when I first watched the pilot, from the very beginning I found it offputting and facile.

The Ranch establishes itself as an easily imbibed, down-home diversion replete with rough edges and mini-lessons to live by... Still, this is by and large a pleasant surprise that advances the ball just a bit further for Kutcher.
A good cast attempts to liven things up in The Ranch, but there's no getting around writing and bottom-barrel humor that's this superficial and exhausting.
Unless you drive a rusty pickup truck with a "NObama" bumper sticker on it, you can probably let this one mosey off into the sunset without so much as a tip of the Stetson.
Once the canned laughter kicks in, the artificial rhythms of setup-punchline mark this as Netflix' attempt to do a bad network sitcom, albeit one that occasionally drops the F-bomb.
Truth be told, it often feels like the series walks the line between an uninspired sitcom and an intelligent stage play.
It's the best show you aren't watching. Don't let it go.
Lack of energy is a problem for this show. It's missing that electricity that makes investing in yet another great man procedural worth it.

The series can boast a unique premise and a promising cast, but the pilot falls short of delivering a truly compelling hour of television... a lot may need to change if Ransom is to have a long future at CBS.
With a ton of shows out there just like it, the trick will be in getting those who already have full TV schedules to make room for a series that doesn't immediately stand out from the crowd.
If you're just looking for another CBS procedural to casually watch on a Saturday night, Ransom is a solid choice.

I never shook the feeling that I was watching something that, from cast to the overall aesthetic, we weren't meant to see on American network TV, except for maybe in the summer when [better] Canadian productions... have thrived.
Ransom could use some caffeine.
For what it is - something serviceable to fit in CBS's Saturday lineup - Ransom will do, but pretty much is a square peg fitting in a square hole.
Its premise is built for adrenaline-rush moments, not for the long haul.
It's not bad television, really. It's just by-the-CBS-book television. Episodes will mostly be self-contained, although the relationship between Beaumont and Carlson will provide a long-game string.
Ransom is easier to take than some of them, and with a hero who doesn't have to brandish a gun to get the job done.
That said, for those looking for an acceptable cat-and-mouse thriller that doesn't make too many demands on the psyche, "Ransom" should fill the bill well enough.
[It is] co-created by Frank Spotnitz (The Man in the High Castle), who is capable of much more interesting work.
If you're a viewer who prefers to not know what will happen next, this will bore the pants off you.
Ransom is a perfectly adequate, by-the-numbers broadcast TV thriller.
Pilot is much more talk than action - did producers really believe that audiences pay to watch action stars, even one with Norris's appeal, develop as sensitive characters?
The weirdness of the case was balanced by nuts-and-bolts details of Winckler's private life.
It's an impressively eerie start to this very good French thriller.
It's a far-fetched set-up, but the level-headed Lieutenant Sandra Winkler (Marie Dompnier) is still on hand to investigate.
Witnesses is nicely paced with judiciously timed reveals and cliffhangers.
What gives Witnesses its own identity is that its particularly morbid plot makes it arguably even creepier than anything else to come out of Scandinavia.
